title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #990: Polynomial Root Distribution**

For polynomial f ∈ ℂ[x] with d roots having arguments θ₁,...,θ_d ∈ [0,2π], is the discrepancy:

|#{θᵢ ∈ I} - |I|d/(2π)| ≪ √(n log M)

where n = number of nonzero coefficients?

**Status:** Classical Erdős-Turán (with d) PROVED; sparse case (with n) OPEN.
mathContext: Complex analysis, equidistribution theory, polynomial root geometry.

title: Complex Polynomial
content:
**ComplexPoly d:** A polynomial of degree at most d represented as a coefficient sequence.

f = a₀ + a₁x + ⋯ + aₐxᵈ where aᵢ ∈ ℂ.

title: Sparsity (Nonzero Coefficients)
content:
**nonzeroCoeffCount d p:** The number of nonzero coefficients in polynomial p.

Examples:
- x^d - 1 has sparsity 2
- x^d + x^(d-1) + ... + x + 1 has sparsity d+1

Sparsity can be much smaller than degree.

title: Complex Argument
content:
**argument z:** The angle θ ∈ [0, 2π) such that z = |z|e^{iθ}.

For a root z of polynomial f, the argument tells us where z lies on the unit circle (after radial projection).

title: Mahler M Measure
content:
**mahlerM d p:** M = (|a₀| + |a₁| + ⋯ + |aₐ|) / √(|a₀||aₐ|)

This normalization factor appears in the Erdős-Turán bound. For monic polynomials with nonzero constant term, M ≥ 2.

title: Root Set
content:
**rootSet d p:** The set of d roots (counted with multiplicity) of polynomial p.

By the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, a degree-d polynomial has exactly d complex roots.

title: Roots in Interval
content:
**rootsInInterval d p α β:** Count of roots with argument in [α, β].

This measures how many roots lie in the angular sector from angle α to β.

title: Expected Count
content:
**expectedCount d α β:** (β - α) · d / (2π)

If d roots were uniformly distributed around the circle, this is how many would fall in [α, β].

title: Discrepancy
content:
**discrepancy d p α β:** |actual count - expected count|

The discrepancy measures how far the root distribution deviates from uniform. The Erdős-Turán inequality bounds this quantity.

title: Maximum Discrepancy
content:
**maxDiscrepancy d p:** sup over all intervals [α,β] of the discrepancy.

This is the worst-case deviation from uniform distribution over all possible angular sectors.

title: Classical Erdős-Turán (1950)
content:
**erdos_turan_classical:**

maxDiscrepancy(p) ≤ C · √(d · log M)

The original 1950 result: polynomial roots cannot cluster too much. The bound depends on degree d and the Mahler measure M.

title: Ganelius Improvement (1954)
content:
**ganelius_improvement:**

The constant C can be taken ≤ 8.

Ganelius improved the explicit constant in the Erdős-Turán inequality just 4 years after the original paper.

title: Sparse Conjecture (The Open Problem)
content:
**sparseConjecture:**

maxDiscrepancy(p) ≤ C · √(n · log M)

where n = number of nonzero coefficients.

This is the OPEN question: can the degree d be replaced by the sparsity n?

title: Sparsity ≤ Degree + 1
content:
**sparse_improves_dense:**

n ≤ d + 1 always.

The sparsity is at most degree + 1, so a sparse bound would always be at least as good as the classical bound.

title: Unity Roots Are Sparse
content:
**unity_root_sparse:**

x^d - 1 has only 2 nonzero coefficients but degree d.

This is the key example motivating the conjecture: roots of unity are perfectly equidistributed, and x^d - 1 is maximally sparse.

title: Sharp Constant (2019-2021)
content:
**sharp_erdos_turan:**

There exists an optimal constant C_sharp such that any valid constant C satisfies C_sharp ≤ C.

Soundararajan (2019) and subsequent work determined the exact optimal constant, ending 70 years of improvement attempts.

title: Hilbert Transform Connection
content:
**hilbert_connection:**

The optimal constant is determined by an extremal problem involving Hilbert transforms and Fourier analysis.

This unexpected connection between polynomial root distribution and harmonic analysis was key to finding the sharp constant.

title: Roots of Unity: Uniform
content:
**unity_roots_uniform:**

The n-th roots of unity (roots of x^n - 1) are exactly uniformly distributed at angles 2πk/n.

This is the perfect case: discrepancy is at most 1 (due to integrality).

title: Littlewood Polynomials
content:
**isLittlewood d p:** All coefficients have absolute value 1 (or are zero).

Littlewood polynomials (coefficients ±1) have special structure and their root distribution is intensively studied.

title: Lower Bound Construction
content:
**lower_bound_construction:**

For every degree d, there exist polynomials with maxDiscrepancy ≥ (1/10)√d.

This shows the √d dependence in Erdős-Turán is necessary—it cannot be improved to o(√d).

title: Erdélyi's One-Sided Improvement
content:
**erdelyi_one_sided:**

The actual count minus expected count (without absolute value) is ≤ C√(d log M).

This subtle one-sided version says roots can cluster below expectation but not too much above.

title: Status Summary
content:
**erdos_990_status:**

1. Classical Erdős-Turán with degree d: PROVED
2. Sparse conjecture with sparsity n: OPEN

The 1950 result is a cornerstone of polynomial root theory; the sparse version remains tantalizing.

title: Main Theorem
content:
**erdos_990:**

Erdős Problem #990: Classical case PROVED, sparse case OPEN.

The question whether polynomial sparsity controls root equidistribution remains one of the elegant open problems in analysis.
